cards.back:
Av = 1 + R2/R1

Note the '+1' — gain is always ≥ 1.

cards.front: Which input receives signal in non-inverting amp?
cards.back:
Non-inverting input (+)

The inverting input (-) connects to the feedback network (R1, R2).

Very high (approaching ∞)

Signal connects directly to op-amp's high-impedance input. No current flows.

cards.front: What is a unity-gain buffer / voltage follower?
cards.back:
Non-inverting amp with Av = 1

R2 = 0 (short), R1 = any value or open
Used for impedance matching.

cards.front: Activity 2 component values and expected gain?
cards.back:
R1 = 2.2kΩ, R2 = 39kΩ
Av = 1 + 39k/2.2k = 18.73

Note: 1 more than inverting with same resistors!

In-phase (0° shift)

Output follows input polarity:
Positive input → positive output
(Unlike inverting which is 180° shifted)

cards.front: Why is minimum gain of non-inverting amp = 1?
cards.back:
Av = 1 + R2/R1

Smallest R2/R1 ratio is 0 (when R2 = 0)
So Av,min = 1 + 0 = 1

1. V+ = Vi (signal at non-inverting input)
2. V- = Vo × R1/(R1+R2) (voltage divider)
3. V- = V+ (virtual short)
4. Solve: Vi = Vo × R1/(R1+R2)
5. Vo/Vi = 1 + R2/R1

cards.front: Inverting vs Non-Inverting: Gain comparison for same R1, R2?
cards.back:
Inverting: |Av| = R2/R1
Non-inverting: Av = 1 + R2/R1

Non-inverting is exactly 1 larger.

cards.front: When to use non-inverting instead of inverting?
cards.back:
Use non-inverting when:
• High input impedance needed
• No phase inversion acceptable
• Gain must be ≥ 1
• Buffering high-impedance sources
